history.content:
1. 189 is an upper division CS course on ML. If you are interested in ML, you could take it but you are not required to, by any means. Many people even graduate without taking the course.

2. Nothing like that. 127 is optimization and 126 is probability & random processes. Both the courses are in some ways related to ML, but again, you are not required to take them.

3. This is a hard question without having information on your background and mathematical maturity. The purpose of taking 126/127 before 189 is to ensure that you are familiar with the advanced math/linear algebra/probability theory involved in the ML material beforehand so that you can focus on learning the core material by itself as you take the course. Now if you already have the said background through other pathways, you could be fine. Nevertheless, 189 is a challenging class, irrespective of whether you've taken 126/127 or not; its just that you might struggle less if you have the suggested background.

4. You always can. But in general, isn't it obvious to you that if you would want a job in a particular field, your employer would expect you to have obtained the necessary background in school and/or have significant experience in that field?

5. Look through the material and see it for yourself. Self-studying habits obviously differ from person to person so it is dependent upon you. I personally think it would be difficult to master the content in 126/127 solely by self-studying but this is just my opinion.

_______________________________________

I would add that it also kind of depends on what you want (just the grade/job, or something more?) performing at an A level in 189 right now in Sahai's course without 126+127, but the class has been a lot more stressful/less 'worth it' for me because i can't focus as much on the applications side of things and find it hard to see how things generalize. If you're in it for the grade, I think you could do well and do an industry job in the field (there are TONS of cookbook style resources out there, and certain ML roles just make you a code monkey with a different set of tools). If you're in it to understand the subject deeply and apply it to previously unsolved problems, and potentially get the more interesting ML industry jobs, then you want 126/27.

children.subject: LOL tbh, if you found 61abc, 188, 170, 100 are easy to self study and also got good grade, then you definitely can take 189 directly without 126 and 127. However, it could be a heavy workload class without 127 and 126 even if you have strong self-learning ability (can be very heavy if you are aiming to get a good grade).

history.content:
The extremely simple answer is that modern machine learning is the application of optimization to learning from data by  modeling the problems using probabilistic and linear algebraic ideas. From this, you can immediately conclude that optimization thinking, probability, and linear algebra are fundamental prerequisites to understanding machine learning. Without them, you will miss the machine learning in a machine learning course, because you'll get bogged down by the other stuff.

In general, we have:

Core underlying ideas --> problem-solving approaches and algorithms

In principle, one could try to learn purely at the level of problem-solving approaches and algorithms. But then, an introductory course on ML would just be one thing after another, with no unity. This would turn into an exercise in memorization. Could you use the approaches in practice? Sure. You could be a useful minion. But then, when in the future, new approaches and algorithms are discovered, you will have to memorize them afresh. Furthermore, if you ever have to modify or combine approaches, you would be left to ordinary software-engineering tinkering/debugging skills. Because you wouldn't actually understand what is going on.

Ideally, a Berkeley student should aim to understand a subject that they are taking. And fortunately, there are *plenty* of online resources that will explain to you the problem-solving approaches and algorithms. You don't need to take 189 for that. So 189 is trying to help you understand. 

There was a reason that the lower-division curriculum was transformed by the introduction of the pre-machine-learning courses 16A and 16B. The goal was to make it easier for people to build to a solid understanding. (And for those who just wanted to pick up algorithms and problem-solving approaches to do so on their own. After all, the core ideas of ordinary least squares, matching pursuit, control and the roles of eigenvalues in convergence, the SVD, least-norm solutions, PCA, classification by hyperplanes, and k-means are all already introduced in EE16AB.) But for the vast majority of people, you need more probability to really understand 189. So if you take one course beyond EE16AB, take EECS126.

Both EECS126 and 127 will serve you well no matter what part of EECS you end up in. Whereas 189 will mainly help you if you go into an area that leverages machine learning specifically. 

Edit:

Our colleague Prof. Jordan has recently posted something that students might benefit from for a larger context: 

https://medium.com/@mijordan3/artificial-intelligence-the-revolution-hasnt-happened-yet-5e1d5812e1e7

children.subject: Thank you so much Professor Sahai!

history.content:
Been answered multiple times, but there have been different perspectives.

1) Is it worth taking 189 if I don't intend on getting masters/phd?

2) Is it worth taking 189 if I don't take 127/126 after?

3) Will it be unnecessarily hard taking 189 next spring without 126/127?

4) Can I still get a Machine Learning internship/job by taking 189 without 126/127?

5) What are the challenges of self studying 126/127? I've found 61a-c, 188, 170, 100 easy to self study.
history.subject: Taking 189 Without 126 and 127
